questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the element of the Finesse API on the left onto its functionality on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
given answer ist correct:
User Represents an agent, supervisor, or administrator.
Dialog Represents a call and the participants if the media type is voice.
Media Represents a user’s state in a non-voice Media Routing Domain.
Queue Represents a skill group in Unified CCE.
Team Represents a group of users.
SystemInfo Represents the current state of the system.
ClientLogs Sends client-side logging to the Finesse Server.

User - Represents an agent, supervisor, or administrator.

Dialog - Represents a call and the participants if the media type is voice.

Media - Represents a user’s state in a non-voice Media Routing Domain.

Queue - Represents a group of users.

Team - Represents a skill group in Unified CCE.

SystemInfo - Represents the current state of the system.

ClientLogs - Sends client-side logging to the Finesse Server.

comments.content: After review the Cisco Docs, I believe my original answer to be wrong and the one posted correct.

discussion.content: It is correct

questions.question_text: What are two key capabilities of Cisco Finesse? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
- Agents access Finesse from a browser without needing to install or configure anything on the client machine.
Finesse is a web-based application that can be accessed from a browser, which means that agents can use it without needing to install or configure anything on their client machine.
- Gadget containers provide a seamless experience in a single user interface.
Finesse includes gadget containers, which are user interface elements that can be used to display gadgets (small web-based applications) within the Finesse user interface. This allows gadgets to be displayed in a seamless and integrated manner within the interface.
E) is not correct, because Cisco Finesse does not uses RPC APIs. It leverages REST APIs

Selected Answer: AC
It's A+C
A and C are the correct answers.

comments.content: Correct, here is the resource https://developer.cisco.com/docs/finesse/#!finesse-overview/technical-overview

choices.C: Gadget containers provide a seamless experience in a single user interface.
choices.A: Agents access Finesse from a browser without needing to install or configure anything on the client machine.
choices.B: An OpenDNS utility is preconfigured and ready to use on Finesse.
choices.E: Finesse includes an RPC API that enables the development of custom gadgets.

choices.C: Cisco Intersight uses XML to encode API interactions and requires an API key pair for authentication.
choices.E: Cisco Intersight API interactions can be encoded in XML or JSON and require an API key in the HTTP header for authentication.
choices.D: UCS Manager API interactions are XML-encoded and require a cookie in the method for authentication.
choices.B: UCS Director API interactions can be XML- or JSON-encoded and require an API key in the HTTP header for authentication.
choices.A: UCS Manager uses JSON to encode API interactions and utilizes Base64-encoded credentials in the HTTP header for authentication.

comments.content: Hi Leo, how about the authentication of Intersight?

discussion.content:
UCSM - XML only
Intersight - JSON only
UCSD - JSON or XML

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct.
UCSM - XML only - Authentication by Cookie
Intersight - JSON only - Authentication by TokenID
UCSD - JSON or XML - Authentication by TokenID (keyID and secretkey) and Session Cookies

comments.content:
